blocks.name: lgseisenlem1
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ lgseisen . If ` R ( u ) = ( Q x. u ) mod P ` and ` M ( u ) = ( -u 1 ^ R ( u ) ) x. R ( u ) ` , then for any even ` 1 <_ u <_ P - 1 ` , ` M ( u ) ` is also an even integer ` 1 <_ M ( u ) <_ P - 1 ` . To simplify these statements, we divide all the even numbers by ` 2 ` , so that it becomes the statement that ` M ( x / 2 ) = ( -u 1 ^ R ( x / 2 ) ) x. R ( x / 2 ) / 2 ` is an integer between ` 1 ` and ` ( P - 1 ) / 2 ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 17-Jun-2015.)

blocks.name: lgseisenlem2
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ lgseisen . The function ` M ` is an injection (and hence a bijection by the pigeonhole principle). (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 17-Jun-2015.)

blocks.name: lgseisenlem4
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ lgseisen . The function ` M ` is an injection (and hence a bijection by the pigeonhole principle). (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 18-Jun-2015.) (Proof shortened by AV, 15-Jun-2019.)

blocks.name: lgseisen
blocks.content: Eisenstein's lemma, an expression for ` ( P /L Q ) ` when ` P , Q ` are distinct odd primes. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 18-Jun-2015.)

blocks.name: lgsquadlem1
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ lgsquad . Count the members of ` S ` with odd coordinates. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 19-Jun-2015.)

blocks.name: lgsquadlem2
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ lgsquad . Count the members of ` S ` with even coordinates, and combine with ~ lgsquadlem1 to get the total count of lattice points in ` S ` (up to parity). (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 18-Jun-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm lgsquadlem2(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wceq(co(c0, clgs, c1), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, cfv(chash, c2))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))))
  -| wi(w0, wne(c1, c0))
  -| wceq(c3, co(co(c1, cmin, nat1), cdiv, nat2))
  -| wceq(c4, co(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cdiv, nat2))
  -| wceq(c2, copab(s0, s1, wa(wa(wcel(cv(s0), co(nat1, cfz, c3)), wcel(cv(s1), co(nat1, cfz, c4))), wbr(co(cv(s1), cmul, c1), clt, co(cv(s0), cmul, c0)))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c3)
  -| diffsc(s0, c4)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c3)
  -| diffsc(s1, c4)
  -| diffsw(s0, w0)

blocks.name: lgsquad
blocks.content: The Law of Quadratic Reciprocity, see also theorem 9.8 in [ApostolNT] p. 185. If ` P ` and ` Q ` are distinct odd primes, then the product of the Legendre symbols ` ( P /L Q ) ` and ` ( Q /L P ) ` is the parity of ` ( ( P - 1 ) / 2 ) x. ( ( Q - 1 ) / 2 ) ` . This uses Eisenstein's proof, which also has a nice geometric interpretation - see ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proofs_of_quadratic_reciprocity . This is Metamath 100 proof #7. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 19-Jun-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm lgsquad(class c0, class c1) {

blocks.name: lgsquad2
blocks.content: Extend ~ lgsquad to coprime odd integers (the domain of the Jacobi symbol). (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 19-Jun-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm lgsquad2(class c0, class c1, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wceq(co(co(c0, clgs, c1), cmul, co(c1, clgs, c0)), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, co(co(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cdiv, nat2), cmul, co(co(c1, cmin, nat1), cdiv, nat2)))))

  -| wi(w0, wn(wbr(nat2, cdvds, c0)))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cn))
  -| wi(w0, wn(wbr(nat2, cdvds, c1)))
  -| wi(w0, wceq(co(c0, cgcd, c1), nat1))
} = {
  lgsquad2lem2(hs2, hs0, hs1, c0, c1, w0, wral(hs0, co(nat1, cfz, cv(hs1)), wi(wceq(co(cv(hs0), cgcd, co(nat2, cmul, c1)), nat1), wceq(co(co(cv(hs0), clgs, c1), cmul, co(c1, clgs, cv(hs0))), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, co(co(co(cv(hs0), cmin, nat1), cdiv, nat2), cmul, co(co(c1, cmin, nat1), cdiv, nat2)))))))

  lgsquad2lem2(hs3, hs0, hs1, c1, cv(hs2), wa(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs2), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wceq(co(cv(hs2), cgcd, c1), nat1))), wral(hs0, co(nat1, cfz, cv(hs1)), wi(wceq(co(cv(hs0), cgcd, co(nat2, cmul, cv(hs2))), nat1), wceq(co(co(cv(hs0), clgs, cv(hs2)), cmul, co(cv(hs2), clgs, cv(hs0))), co(cneg(nat1), cexp, co(co(co(cv(hs0), cmin, nat1), cdiv, nat2), cmul, co(co(cv(hs2), cmin, nat1), cdiv, nat2)))))))

  neneqd(nat2, cv(hs2), wa(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs2), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wceq(co(cv(hs2), cgcd, c1), nat1))))
  necomd(nat2, cv(hs2), wa(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs2), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wceq(co(cv(hs2), cgcd, c1), nat1))))

  eldifsni(cv(hs2), cprime, nat2)
  sylancr(wa(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs2), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wceq(co(cv(hs2), cgcd, c1), nat1))), wb(wbr(nat2, cdvds, cv(hs2)), wceq(nat2, cv(hs2))), wcel(nat2, cfv(cuz, nat2)), wcel(cv(hs2), cprime))
  ax-mp(wcel(nat2, cfv(cuz, nat2)), wcel(nat2, cz))
  2z()
  uzid(nat2)
  dvdsprm(nat2, cv(hs2))
  eqtrd(co(c1, cgcd, cv(hs2)), nat1, co(cv(hs2), cgcd, c1), wa(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs2), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wceq(co(cv(hs2), cgcd, c1), nat1))))

  impr(wa(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs2), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wceq(co(cv(hs2), cgcd, c1), nat1))), wcel(cv(hs3), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wceq(co(cv(hs3), cgcd, cv(hs2)), nat1), wne(cv(hs3), cv(hs2)))
  biimpd(wa(wa(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs2), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wceq(co(cv(hs2), cgcd, c1), nat1))), wcel(cv(hs3), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2)))), wceq(co(cv(hs3), cgcd, cv(hs2)), nat1), wne(cv(hs3), cv(hs2)))
  syl2anr(wa(w0, wa(wcel(cv(hs2), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wceq(co(cv(hs2), cgcd, c1), nat1))), wcel(cv(hs3), cdif(cprime, csn(nat2))), wb(wceq(co(cv(hs3), cgcd, cv(hs2)), nat1), wne(cv(hs3), cv(hs2))), wcel(cv(hs3), cprime), wcel(cv(hs2), cprime))

blocks.name: m1lgs
blocks.content: The first supplement to the law of quadratic reciprocity. Negative one is a square mod an odd prime ` P ` iff ` P == 1 ` (mod ` 4 ` ). See first case of theorem 9.4 in [ApostolNT] p. 181. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 19-Jun-2015.)

blocks.name: 2lgs
blocks.content: The second supplement to the law of quadratic reciprocity (for the Legendre symbol extended to arbitrary primes as second argument). Two is a square modulo a prime ` P ` iff ` P == +- 1 ` (mod ` 8 ` ), see first case of theorem 9.5 in [ApostolNT] p. 181. This theorem justifies our definition of ` ( N /L 2 ) ` ( ~ lgs2 ) to some degree, by demanding that reciprocity extend to the case ` Q = 2 ` . (Proposed by Mario Carneiro, 19-Jun-2015.) (Contributed by AV, 16-Jul-2021.)

blocks.name: 2lgsoddprmlem4
2lgsoddprm
blocks.content: The second supplement to the law of quadratic reciprocity for odd primes (common representation, see theorem 9.5 in [ApostolNT] p. 181): The Legendre symbol for ` 2 ` at an odd prime is minus one to the power of the square of the odd prime minus one divided by eight ( ` ( 2 /L P ) ` = -1^(((P^2)-1)/8) ). (Contributed by AV, 20-Jul-2021.)
